title: Bermuda braces for direct hit from Hurricane Ernesto
message:
This satellite image obtained from the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration shows Hurricane Ernesto bearing down on Bermuda, prompting hurricane warnings (Handout)Bermuda was on high alert Friday as residents brace for Hurricane Ernesto, with heavy rain and flooding expected to wallop the island at the weekend, meteorologists and officials said.
"Ernesto is forecast to be a large hurricane near Bermuda on Saturday and maintain hurricane strength through the weekend," the NHC said in its latest advisory.
The large storm, currently a Category 2 hurricane on the five-level Saffir-Simpson scale, is set to strengthen overnight.
As the territory's emergency officials met Thursday, Minister of National Security Michael Weeks urged residents to complete their hurricane preparation as soon as possible.
Some key roads were closing Friday ahead of the storm, and bus and ferry services were being suspended, it added.

message:

Beryl, developed in the Atlantic Ocean, is now shifting toward the Caribbean Sea.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is 445 miles east-southeast of Isla Beata Dominican Republic and 775 miles east-southeast of Kingston Jamaica, with maximum sustained wind of 165 mph.
A Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.

title: Ernesto Approaches Bermuda , Could Become Category 2 Hurricane
message:
Bermuda is expected to begin facing tropical storm conditions on Aug. 16 as Hurricane Ernesto nears the island, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC).
Ernesto strengthened to a Category 2 hurricane, with increased sustained winds of 100 mph.
The Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale gives a Category 2 hurricane sustained winds of 96 mph—110 mph.
A Category 3 hurricane has winds of 111 mph—129 mph.
The NHC reported swells causing life-threatening surf and rip currents generated by Ernesto are affecting Turks and Caicos, and the Bahamas.

title: Half of Puerto Rico without power as Hurricane Ernesto approaches Bermuda
message:
Hurricane Ernesto notched 90mph maximum sustained winds on Thursday night as it moves toward Bermuda in the Atlantic Ocean.
The National Hurricane Center announced a hurricane warning for Bermuda.
Additional strengthening is forecast, which would put Ernesto close to Category 3 major hurricane status when it reaches the island.
6 to 12 inches of rain could fall on Bermuda Saturday, with some places seeing as much as 15 inches.
Storm wrecks Puerto Rico power gridsHalf of Puerto Rico was waking up on Thursday in the dark, where more than 325,000 customers were still without power as cleanup efforts got underway.

title: Hurricane Ernesto : Hurricane Ernesto : Bermuda on alert as storm grows stronger , power outages and flooding continue in Puerto Rico

title: Massive storm exposes growing threat looming over cities in the U . S . South :  A constant existential fear
message:
In Charleston, South Carolina, the storm revealed just how vulnerable the city is to extreme weather events, which are becoming more common and more intense, the Washington Post reported.
Why are extreme weather events concerning?
The prospect of flooding is "virtually just a constant existential fear we have throughout the year," Charleston resident Damon Black told the Post.
Unfortunately, many of the places most affected by this extreme weather, such as Florida, are moving away from solutions meant to curb the trend.
In order to truly address the threat that extreme weather events pose, we must halt the overheating of our planet caused by dirty energy.

title: Hurricane Ernesto To Create Dangerous Beach Conditions Along East Coast
message:
Hurricane Ernesto, the third hurricane of the season, is heading towards Bermuda, bringing with it the threat of life-threatening rip currents along the East Coast.
The hurricane, which has already caused damage in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, is currently moving north at 14 mph, just east of the Bahamas.
With maximum sustained winds of 85 mph, Ernesto is a Category 1 hurricane, just 9 mph away from a Category 2 designation, according to the National Hurricane Center.
While the storm is not projected to make direct landfall on the U.S., forecasters expect it to bring dangerous swells to the East Coast over the weekend.
The National Hurricane Center has warned people on the East Coast to prepare for a significant risk of life-threatening surf and rip currents.

title: Hurricane Ernesto : Residents of eastern Newfoundland warned to prepare for flooding – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
HALIFAX – The Canadian Hurricane Centre says Hurricane Ernesto could cause coastal flooding in parts of eastern Newfoundland on Monday.
Ernesto — now a Category 2 storm near Bermuda — is expected to track well south and east of Nova Scotia on Monday, though its outer bands may deliver some downpours to the province on Monday and Monday night.
“Beachgoers and sightseers are encouraged to exercise caution,” the centre’s statement said, adding that the ocean swells could cause hazardous surf and rip currents.

title: Hurricane Ernesto strengthens as it barrels to Bermuda
message:
Hurricanes Gonzalo in 2014 and Fabian in 2003 were the most destructive storms to hit Bermuda in recent memory, causing hundreds of millions of dollars in damage and leaving most of the islands without electricity.
Fabian killed four people, the first storm to cause deaths on the islands since 1926.

title: Hurricane Ernesto nears Bermuda as Puerto Rico outages persist
message:
Now a Category 1 hurricane, Ernesto is forecast to strengthen into a much more powerful hurricane before it reaches Bermuda late today, a British island territory far out in the Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) said.
“Strengthening is forecast during the next day or so, and Ernesto could be near major hurricane strength by Friday,” the NHC said.
Ernesto became a hurricane on Wednesday after leaving Puerto Rico as a tropical storm, where it battered the island with heavy rainfall.
Five years earlier, Hurricanes Irma and Maria destroyed the island’s power grid and caused outages in some areas that lasted nearly a year.
Ernesto is the fifth named Atlantic storm of what is expected to be an intense hurricane season.

title: Hurricane Ernesto will hit Bermuda with life - threatening flooding and 100 mph winds
message:
Hurricane Ernesto is set to bring life-threatening flooding, storm surges and winds of up to 100 mph to Bermuda, forecasters said, with dangerous conditions beginning Friday before the storm hits the island in the next 24 hours.
The Category 2 storm is 255 miles southwest of the North Atlantic island and moving at 13 mph, the National Hurricane Center said in an 8 a.m. update.
A hurricane warning has been issued for the entire island and up to 15 inches of rain is expected.
Hurricane-force winds of at least 74 mph are expected Extend 70 miles from the storm’s center, while tropical storm force winds of at least 39 mph can be felt 265 miles away.
Satellite image shows Hurricane Ernesto approaching Bermuda.

title: On heels of Debby , exploring how hurricanes form
message:
We are amid a busy 2024 hurricane season, running from June 1 until Nov. 30.
The forecasters predicted 17 to 25 tropical storms (winds of 39 mph or higher) this year, with eight to 13 of those becoming hurricanes (winds greater than 74 mph) and four to seven of those hurricanes developing into major hurricanes.
Back in August of 2021 the remnants of Tropical Storm Fred dumped 7.64 inches of rain in Auburn, and Debby last week dropped over 5 inches in parts of CNY.
The winds that most often contribute to tropical storm formation originate from the easterly winds crossing over Africa.
The process that creates La Nina or El Nino is a complicated process worthy of its own Eco Talk.

title: How Hurricane Ernesto Could Impact Your Travels
message:
Hurricane Ernesto, then a tropical storm, knocked out power for half of Puerto Rico on Wednesday and is moving toward Bermuda with increased strength.
In Puerto Rico, tropical storm conditions have passed, according to a Thursday travel advisory from Discover Puerto Rico, the island’s Destination Marketing Organization.
However, parts of Vieques, Culebra, and the eastern coast of Puerto Rico are still recovering from heavy rains, flash floods, and tropical winds.
In Florida, Fort Lauderdale International Airport (FLL) and Miami International Airport (MIA) saw delay rates of 88.35% and 91.11% respectively, while Palm Beach International Airport (PBI), Southwest Florida International Airport (RSW), and Sarasota Bradenton International Airport (SRQ ) saw 100% of flights delayed.
Norwegian Cruise LineThree Norwegian Cruise Line itineraries have also been modified as result of Hurricane Ernesto.

title: Hurricane Ernesto Triggers Rip Current Warnings for New Jersey Beaches
message:
Hurricane Ernesto, a strengthening Category 1 storm, is set to bring dangerous swimming conditions to many New Jersey beaches this weekend.
Although the hurricane will remain well offshore, it is expected to generate large swells and dangerous rip currents along the New Jersey and Delaware beaches.
The hurricane center expects Ernesto to spend the weekend near Bermuda before arcing toward the northeast and off the New England coast.
The effects of Ernesto may be evident as early as Friday, with the rip current risk possibly lingering into Monday, and possibly Tuesday.
According to the National Weather Service, "The rip current risk will be high pretty much from Miami to Maine.”In addition to rip currents, the Jersey shore could experience gusts of wind up to 30 miles per hour.

title: August warmth closes the workweek with dry skies . Changes looming for the weekend
message:
Today, we continue with dry conditions and abundant sunshine as daytime highs bump a degree or two above seasonal norms with high pressure in control over Utah today.
Drier and warmer weather returns for our late week, but a more active and wetter pattern arrives for the weekend.
Roughly 89 percent of Utah is experiencing abnormally dry conditions, but we do have more moisture in the forecast!
This moisture looks to linger into early next week, so keep those eyes to the skies starting this weekend!
The current weather pattern suggests we return to a drier and seasonal pattern by mid-late next week.

title: Hurricane Ernesto will bring dangerous swimming conditions , rain to Long Island this weekend
message:
Hurricane Ernesto is set to bring dangerous swimming conditions and rainy weather to Long Island this weekend, as the Category 2 hurricane is expected to pass through Bermuda on Saturday.
Ramunni said that while Hurricane Ernesto will be “pretty close” to Bermuda, if not directly hit the island, the storm will remain offshore to the east of Long Island.
However, Ernesto will create dangerous swimming conditions on Long Island and a rip current statement is in effect until Saturday at 9 p.m. for all South Shore beaches.
Long Island will mostly see showers and possible thunderstorms late Sunday into Monday, Ramunni said.
“But I would plan to have an umbrella handy.”The silver lining is that the storm will head east and offshore by Tuesday, and Long Island will see dry and less-humid conditions.

title: 3 Tips to Prepare Supply Chains for Record Hurricane Season
message:
NOAA's outlook for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, which spans from June 1 to November 30, predicts an 85% chance of an above-normal season, leading to the high likelihood of frequent supply chain disruptions.
Hurricane season also falls at the same time peak shipping season is starting, creating a domino effect of supply chain disruptions that can affect the holiday season if not handled properly.
This hurricane season, shippers in high-risk areas like Florida and Louisiana should develop a diverse carrier network now to navigate crises effectively.
Make sure a backup supply is also available, in case the supply chain disruption is longer than a few days.
Follow the updates on impact from your supply chain visibility provider or supply chain news outlets to determine next steps.

title: Taiwan hit by a 6 . 1 - magnitude earthquake : CENC
message:
A 6.1-magnitude earthquake jolted the waters off Hualien County in China's Taiwan at 7:35 a.m. Friday (Beijing Time), according to the China Earthquake Networks Center (CENC).
The quake struck at a depth of 16 km, said a report issued by the CENC.
Previously, warning was issued after southwestern Japan was jolted on Thursday by a strong 7.1 magnitude earthquake, forcing Prime Minister Fumio Kishida to cancel his trip to Central Asia on Friday.
It is the “first such advisory for areas around the Nankai Trough” -- stretching from southwestern to central Japan -- issued by Japan Meteorological Agency, Tokyo-based Kyodo News reported.

title: Nature  needs £3 billion climate support
message:
Drought is now the biggest threat to important sites for nature across the UK as the climate changes, a report from The Wildlife Trusts has warned.
The report examining the dangers posed to nature reserves cared for by the trusts also points to pollution, invasive species and habitat fragmentation as key current risks to wildlife in woods, peatlands, wetlands, coastal areas and grasslands.
Over the next 30 years, Wildlife Trusts experts believe drought will continue to pose the biggest threat to their reserves, with other climate-driven risks including heatwaves and wildfires also causes for high concern.
The Wildlife Trusts warned that flooding, rather than drought, is often at the top of the list of hazards that politicians and governments use to discuss climate impacts.
Drought planning needs more urgent attention alongside the other key hazards associated with climate change, the report urges.

title: Stronger Nankai Trough alert likely to cause more confusion | The Asahi Shimbun : Breaking News , Japan News and Analysis
message:
The lifting of the Nankai Trough megaquake advisory came after a tense week, which raises fears even greater confusion could ensue in the event a higher-level “alert” becomes necessary.
The megaquake advisory was lifted on Aug. 15 after no significant changes were observed in crustal movements for seven days.
The Cabinet Office does not know how many people would be asked to evacuate in advance if a megaquake alert is issued.
In principle, transportation companies will also decide on their own how to respond to a megaquake alert.
There are no standards on actions that utilities are expected to take in the event of a megaquake alert.

message:
Residents in parts of Japan are being ordered to evacuate with some homes losing power on Friday as Typhoon Ampil approaches the coast near Tokyo, CNN reported.
The storm is expected to continue intensifying in the next 12 hours, potentially reaching its peak as it passes near Japan.
The storm is forecasted to hit the area by late Friday, bringing strong winds and heavy rain.

If it stays offshore and only brushes the coast, it might only have a light impact on Japan, bringing rain and wind to some areas including Tokyo.

title: Ernesto Becomes Category 2 Hurricane as It Heads to Bermuda
message:
Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 hurricane as it plowed northward toward Bermuda, threatening to drench the British territory with heavy rain and unleash flash floods.
The storm was 410 miles (660 kilometers) south-southwest of Bermuda according to an advisory from the US National Hurricane Center as of 11 p.m. in New York.
Its top winds reached 100 miles per hour, making it a Category 2 hurricane on the five-step Saffir-Simpson scale.
Ernesto is expected to become a major Category 3 hurricane by about 2 p.m. Friday as it approaches Bermuda, but may weaken again by the time it reaches the island Saturday morning, according to AccuWeather Inc.
Photograph: Police block a flooded road as Tropical Storm Ernesto passes through Fajardo, Puerto Rico.

title: Japan orders evacuations near Tokyo as Typhoon Ampil approaches
message:
Hundreds of thousands of people are being advised to evacuate in parts of Japan, with some homes losing power on Friday, as Typhoon Ampil approaches the east coast near the capital.
Ampil has rapidly intensified over the past two days, partly because it moved over very warm water – meaning more moisture in the air to fuel the typhoon.
It could strengthen further in the next 12 hours, with the storm reaching peak intensity as it passes by Japan.
The storm’s center is expected to remain slightly offshore as it turns toward the northeast and moves away from Japan, according to the JTWC and Japan’s Meteorological Agency.
If it stays offshore and only brushes the coast, it might only have a light impact on Japan, bringing rain and wind to some areas including Tokyo.

title: Hope for costly Ike Dike funding restored with adoption of $56 billion statewide flood plan – Houston Public Media
message:
File photoThe Texas Water Development Board on Thursday adopted Texas’ first $56 billion statewide flood plan— restoring hope for the long-anticipated Ike Dike and other coastal flood mitigation projects.
“Texas’ statewide flood planning program is the first of its kind,” Reem Zoun, a Water Development Board director said.
Under the project, around $49 billion will be diverted to flood mitigation projects.
Approximately one in six people in Texas live or work in known flood hazard areas, according to flood plan documents.
Other mitigation projects outlined in the statewide flood plan include Houston-area floodplain analyses, stormwater detention basins and deep tunnel systems for stormwater management.

title: When Hurricane Season Occurs In Galveston , Texas ( And How Serious The Risk Is )
message:
There's a good reason that colorful cottage you booked for a getaway to Galveston Island, home to one of the country's best beaches for a family vacation, sits high up on stilts.
As a barrier island, Galveston is positioned to take the brunt of storm surge during a hurricane — up to 16 feet of surge in the event of a Category 4 storm like the one in 1900 that went down in history as the Great Galveston Hurricane, still considered the worst weather disaster in US history.
AdvertisementPeak hurricane season on the Texas Gulf Coast occurs in August and September — the 1900 storm struck in September, as did 2008's Hurricane Ike — but the official season is much longer, from June 1 through November 30.
That's why the local tourist industry was surprised but not unprepared on July 8, 2024, when Category 1 Hurricane Beryl roared into town so early in the season.
While there is good reason to be prudent when planning your trip to the Gulf Coast (trip insurance?

title: Rare sighting :  Doomsday fish  found near Southern California shore
message:
SAN DIEGO (KSWB/KUSI) – In a rare and perhaps ominous sighting, an oarfish was found floating near California’s La Jolla Shores over the weekend.
Several people then worked together to carry the sea creature from the ocean to the bed of a truck using a paddleboard.
While most oarfish measure anywhere from 10 to 30 feet long, Hook confirmed that this one was right at 12 feet long.
Just a couple days after the oarfish sighting in La Jolla, an earthquake with a magnitude of 4.4 shook Southern California about 2.5 miles south, southeast of Highland Park near Los Angeles.
“Experts don’t have any evidence to theorize why these fish are washing ashore in Southern California, but learn more from each specimen that is collected,” said Hook.

title: P . E . I . officials preparing for hurricane season in a post - Fiona world
message:
As officials in Prince Edward Island prepare for hurricane season, they are urging Islanders to get ready for future Fiona-level storms — whenever they may hit.
Since storm season began, the utility company has been circulating hurricane preparedness information in bill inserts and on its website.
On the municipal level, the Charlottetown Fire Department says it has been working with organizations in the community as it prepares for the height of the Atlantic hurricane season, which officially ends on Nov. 30.
Charlottetown Fire Chief Tim Mamye said Islanders should prepare a 72-hour emergency kit for hurricane season.
(Wayne Thibodeau/CBC)To prepare for hurricane season, Mamye recommended Islanders familiarize themselves with the municipal, provincial and federal advice on getting ready for an emergency.

title: Very strong  Typhoon Ampil prompts storm warnings as it nears eastern Japan
message:
Typhoon Ampil was moving past eastern Japan on Friday as a “very strong” storm, bringing heavy winds and torrential rain to a wide area.
Level 4 evacuation orders were issued in the Chiba Prefecture cities of Mobara and Asahi, as well as in the city of Iwaki, Fukushima Prefecture.
Level 3 advisories, encouraging the elderly and those with disabilities to evacuate, were issued in various cities in Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa, Ibaraki and Fukushima prefectures.
On the Sobu Rapid and Keiyo lines, trains running directly from Chiba Prefecture have been canceled.
The Shonan-Shinjuku Line is also facing severe disruptions, with services suspended all day between Odawara in Kanagawa Prefecture and Takasaki in Gunma Prefecture.

title: Why Bermuda is among the most hurricane - resilient areas
message:
Since reliable data started to be kept by meteorologists in the 1800s, 90 cyclones have passed within 50 miles or less of Bermuda.
During the early 20th century, Bermuda experienced a string of powerful hurricanes, which resulted in strict building standards.

A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.

Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

title: Hurricane Ernesto Aims for Bermuda After Leaving Many in Puerto Rico Without Power or Water
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico—Hurricane Ernesto barreled toward Bermuda on Thursday after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water as sweltering heat enveloped the U.S. territory, raising concerns about people’s health.
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island on Saturday.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

barreled toward Bermuda on Thursday after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water as sweltering heat enveloped the U.S. territory, raising concerns about people’s health.

title: Pizza owner gives back to neighborhood dealing with flooding after heavy rain from Tropical Storm Debby
message:
Pizza shop owner gives back to neighborhood dealing with flooding after heavy rain from Tropical Storm DebbyCHARLESTON COUNTY, S.C. (WCBD) — Over a week after Tropical Storm Debby made a second landfall in the Lowcountry many communities are still dealing with the flooding effects.
One local restaurant owner was looking for a way to give back after the storm.
Mike Pitera, owner of Pizza a Modo Mio, used his culinary skills to help out those hit hardest by Edisto River flooding.
“There’s a lot of people who can’t get out their houses are underwater their driveways are underwater,” said Melissa Mitchum.
If you’d like to show Mike some support — you can visit Pizza a Modo Mio on Bees Ferry Road.

title: Rainforest Caribbean , NCB , JSE partner on support for fisheries sector
message:
The hurricane-ravaged fisheries sector has received well-needed support from a coalition partnership of Rainforest Caribbean, National Commercial Bank (NCB) and the Jamaica Social Stock Exchange.
Rainforest, the region’s leading seafood supplier, donated $5 million, which was matched by NCB’s Building a Better Jamaica Fund in a collective effort to rebuild the sector in the aftermath of Hurricane Beryl.
A release noted that the companies handed over the $10 million donation to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Mining at the annual Denbigh Agricultural Show in Clarendon on August 6.
Rainforest Caribbean is the region’s trailblazing seafood supplier, distributor and manufacturer with its headquarters in Jamaica and locations in St Lucia, Barbados, Belize and St Vincent and the Grenadines.
NCB’s Building a Better Jamaica Fund was launched by National Commercial Bank Jamaica Limited in response to the devastating impact of Hurricane Beryl and is being managed by the NCB Foundation.

title: Opinion | Check fine print on insurance for quakes
message:
Photo: Jonathan WongAll this has prompted reflection on consumer protection in these circumstances under travel insurance policies.
According to a memo issued by the federation, most policies bought after the quake will not cover any related incidents.
Insurance consumers are not renowned for studying policy conditions in fine print that define their insurance cover.
So Lau’s advice to check any doubts about coverage with insurers before departing, and to buy any insurance as soon as a trip is confirmed, seems sensible.
If insurance is needed for peace of mind, some of that research should focus on the best value cover for money.

title: Ernesto grows into Category 2 hurricane as it aims for Bermuda , leaving many in Puerto Rico without power
message:
A hurricane warning was in effect for Bermuda, with Ernesto expected to pass near or over the island Saturday.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto strengthened into a Category 2 storm Thursday night as it barreled toward Bermuda after leaving hundreds of thousands of people in Puerto Rico without power or water.
“All of the guidance show this system as a large hurricane near Bermuda,” said the National Hurricane Center in Miami.
Crews have flown more than 540 miles (870 kilometers) across Puerto Rico and identified 400 power line failures, with 150 of them already fixed, said Juan Saca, president of Luma Energy, a private company that operates the transmission and distribution of power in Puerto Rico.
At least 250,000 customers across Puerto Rico also were without water given the power outages, down from a maximum of 350,000.

title: Forsyth Farmer Market hosts fundraiser for vendors impacted by Debby
message:
SAVANNAH, Ga. (WSAV) – The Forsyth Farmers’ Market is stepping up to help some of their vendors who were impacted by Tropical Storm Debby.
Their “Roots in Recovery” fundraiser aims to help repair damages, replace lost crops and ensure vendors can continue their vital work.
“These are the same farmers who have tirelessly brought nutritious produce to our community, rain or shine, season after season,” the fundraising page reads.
“Now, they need our help to recover and rebuild.”WSAV News 3, iHeart Media and Parker’s Kitchen raise money for victims of Tropical Storm DebbyTo contribute to the fundraiser, visit here.
The market is held each Saturday from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. in Savannah’s Forsyth Park.

title: Hurricane Debby exposes vulnerabilities for neighbors in Perry
message:
Hurricane Debby exposes additional vulnerabilities for neighbors in Taylor County who say they cannot afford basic necessities and building repairs.
BROADCAST TRANSCRIPT:More people struggling to afford groceries and make ends meet since Hurricane Debby.
Damage from Hurricane Idalia and then Debby has caused major water damage.
Monique Ellsworth, CEO of Second Harvest of the Big Bend, said over 20% of their post Debby distribution has gone to Taylor County.
However, Ellsworth said there is also an air of relief in Taylor County that damage was minimal.

title: Greece fires : Photos show how close Athens wildfires came to burning whole towns
message:

Brutal, rolling heat waves have dried out the land, creating ideal conditions for fires to rip through.

title: Hurricane Ernesto barrels toward Bermuda as wealthy British territory preps for storm
message:
Tropical storm conditions including strong winds and life-threatening floods were expected to start affecting Bermuda on Friday afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory announced they would suspend public transportation and close the airport by Friday night.
Ernesto previously battered the northeast Caribbean, where it left hundreds of thousands of people without power and water in Puerto Rico after swiping past the U.S. territory as a tropical storm.

title: Vermont flooding : Examining what behind all the heavy rain
message:
But what’s driving such extreme and sudden flooding in Vermont from a meteorological perspective?
The rain doesn’t let upThe average annual precipitation across Vermont has been increasing at alarming rates, with the northern regions of New England accelerating faster than the south.
“Vermont watersheds are particularly small and steep and that makes them more prone to flooding,” Winter said.
AdvertisementSurface storm systems have a tendency to produce the strongest storms closest to wherever the jet stream is positioned overhead.
Recently, the jet stream has been positioned by nearby Vermont, making the area more susceptible to frequent and intense storms.

title: Hochul Declares State Of Emergency For All Of NY , Sends Water Rescue Teams
message:
The declaration came on Friday, Aug. 9 after Debby's remnants arrived in New York, bringing severe flooding and gusty winds to much of the state as it moves northeast.
In addition to flooding, the storm system's arrival has also prompted tornado watches for parts of the Hudson Valley and Capital Region.
Hochul's declaration covers the entire state.
Agencies are also preparing to support heavily impacted regions with resources as needed, officials said.
The remnants are expected to continue through Friday night before precipitation gradually stops on Saturday morning, Aug. 10.

title: Kano , Lagos Lead as States Receive N39 . 6bn Ecological Funds in One Year – THISDAYLIVE
message:
The fund’s disbursement process is managed by the Ecological Fund Office, under the Office of the Secretary to the Government of the Federation (SGF).
Borno State, which is dealing with environmental damage linked to the insurgency, received N1.68 billion (averaging N140million per month), the second-highest allocation.
Other top recipients of the ecological fund include Lagos with N1.81 billion (averaging N150.83million per month), Kaduna with N1.4 billion (averaging N124.17million per month), and Sokoto with N1.49 billion (averaging N124.17million per month).
Edo received N632.8million (averaging N52.73million per month), and Abia received N633.68million (averaging N52.81million per month).
Enugu received N1.36 billion (averaging N113.33million per month) for its ecological interventions.
